message.content:
We must “filter‐in” only those cash transactions that are related to the day‐to‐day operations (for example, expenses and receipts from “core operations”) while (a) leaving out receipts that come from “deposit” or “issue of equity” and (b) “purchases” of equipment and “fixed asset” transactions plus “transfers” (which are usually investing/financing items). In our “problem” table all “Sale” lines (of Heavy Equipment) are considered proceeds from the sale of property – i.e. investing dues – and therefore are not “operating”  

Also, note that non‐cash adjustments such as “Depreciation” are not “paid” and do not affect the actual cash flow (so we ignore depreciation here when computing a “direct‐view” net operating cash flow). Finally, several “Interest Receivables” are recorded as “Unpaid” so they do not represent cash received.

In the table the only “operating” cash “payment” lines are those whose “type” is “Expense” (whether labeled “Administrative Expenses,” “Sales Expenses” or “Financial Expenses”). We can ignore all “Sale” transactions (all relate to heavy equipment), all “Purchase” transactions (which are capital expenditures) and all “Transfers” (cash‐to‐bank or bank‐to‐cash) plus the “Initial” and “Fixed Assets” ones.

A step–by–step approach (we show the “expense” cash outflows only):

1. On 2024‑01‑01 Administrative Expenses: 22,627.45  
2. On 2024‑01‑02 Sales Expenses: 46,979.81

51. On 2024‑02‑05 Sales Expenses: 67,892.84

When these operating cash “outflows” are summed we obtain approximately 2,750,905.22 (all amounts in the local currency).

Since there are no actual operating cash inflows (the “Sale” transactions all involve capital – heavy equipment – and the interest ones are “Unpaid”), the net cash flow from operating activities is simply the negative of the total operating cash outflow.

Thus the final Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities is about –2,750,905.22.

The answer in the required format is:

{"solution": {"Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities": "-2750905.22"} }
